questions.question_text: Which workflow action type performs a secondary search?

choices.B: The data model must be de-accelerated before edits can be made to its structure.
choices.D: An accelerated data model can be edited from the Pivot tool.
choices.A: It cannot be edited. A new data model would need to be created.
choices.C: An accelerated data model can be edited once its .tsidx file has expired.

questions.question_text: How can an existing accelerated data model be edited?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The question is "how" an accelerated data model is edited, not "should" it be edited. If you accelerate a data model and attempt to edit it, you receive a warning message: "This Data Model cannot be edited because it is accelerated. Disable acceleration in order to edit the Data Model."

The answer is B

Selected Answer: B
Docs show that you aren't recommended to, but this question is simply asking if you can. Which you can but it must be disabled first.

Selected Answer: B
The document says its not recommended.. it doesn't say that there is no way to edit an accelerated data model. The question is very straight forward. So I would assume they're looking for a straight forward answer. It must be B in my opinion

Selected Answer: A
After you accelerate a data model, you cannot edit it.
To make changes to an accelerated data model, you must disable its acceleration. Reaccelerating the data model can be resource-intensive, so it's best to avoid disabling acceleration if you can.

"After you accelerate a data model, you cannot edit it. To make changes to an accelerated data model, you must disable its acceleration. Reaccelerating the data model can be resource-intensive, so it's best to avoid disabling acceleration if you can." https://docs.splunk.com/Documentation/Splunk/9.3.0/Knowledge/Managedatamodels#:~:text=After%20you%20accelerate%20a%20data,disabling%20acceleration%20if%20you%20can.
Accelerated data models cannot be edited

questions.question_text: Which of the following is true about data sets used in the Pivot tool?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Answer is D:
Explanation:
A. They can only be created from summary indexes.: This is incorrect. While summary indexes can be used in Splunk, data sets for the Pivot tool specifically derive from data models, not solely from summary indexes.

B. They can only be created by users with the Admin role.: This is false. While users with Admin roles can create and manage data models, users with appropriate permissions can create data sets in the Pivot tool.

C. They can only be created from saved reports.: This is also incorrect. Data sets in the Pivot tool are derived specifically from data models rather than saved reports.

D. They can only be created from data models.: This is true. The Pivot tool relies on data models to create data sets for analysis and visualization

choices.B: They can only be created by users with the Admin role.
choices.C: They can only be created from saved reports.
choices.D: They can only be created from data models.
choices.A: They can only be created from summary indexes.

questions.question_text: Which of the following expressions could be used to create a calculated field called megabytes?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C looks like the answer

comments.content: mod please delete, i i wrote the wrong explanation but it's A

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The correct answer is D. | eval notNULL = "" fillnull value=0 notNULL
Option A is incorrect because it is missing a comma between the "0" and the notNULL in the if function. The correct syntax for the if function is if (condition, true_value, false_value).
Option B is incorrect because it is missing the false_value argument in the if function. The correct syntax for the if function is if (condition, true_value, false_value).
Option C is incorrect because it uses the nullfill command, which only replaces null values, not empty strings. The nullfill command is equivalent to fillnull value=null.
Option D is correct because it uses the eval command to assign an empty string to the notNULL field, and then uses the fillnull command to replace the empty string with a zero. The fillnull command can replace any value with a specified replacement, not just null values.
